questions.question: A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, delivered a healthy baby girl via normal vaginal delivery. She is now 2 weeks postpartum and presents for a follow-up visit. On examination, her uterus is not palpable per abdomen. What best describes the normal puerperium duration and uterine involution weight in this patient?

options.A: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams
options.B: Puerperium is until 8 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 500 grams
options.C: Puerperium is until 9 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 1000 grams
options.D: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 100 grams

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams Explanation : Puerperium defines the time following delivery during which pregnancy-induced maternal anatomical and physiological changes return to the nonpregnant state. Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and is considered to last between 4 and 6 weeks. Involution of uterus in puerperium : Duration Weight of uterus Uterus palpable Immediately after delivery 1000gm (Option C) Just below the umbilicus *for 1st 24 hours no change in fundal height. Thereafter, FH decreases @ about 1.25 cm/day. Fundal height approx. 1 finger breath below the umbilicus on the 2nd postpartum day. 1 week after delivery 500gm (Option B) Midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis 2 weeks after delivery 300gm (Option A) Not palpable (becomes pelvic organ) 4 weeks after delivery 100gm (Option D) Involutes completely Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 634, 635, 636 2. DC Dutta Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 138

questions.question: A 30-year-old female who delivered a healthy term baby one week ago is now presenting to the OBG clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling pale brownish vaginal discharge. What is the nature of this discharge?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lochia Serosa Explanation: Lochia Serosa is usually seen from the 5th to the 9th day of puerperium, the color of discharge is yellowish, pink, or pale brownish (Option B) Lochia is the vaginal discharge seen in early puerperium due to the sloughing of decidual tissue. It has an offensive fishy smell and may last up to 35 days. Depending upon the variation of the colour, the types of Lochia are: Type of Lochia Timing Composition Lochia Rubra -red ( Option A ) Seen in 1-4 days Blood Shreds of fetal membranes and decidua Vernix caseosa Lanugo and meconium. Lochia Serosa-yellowish or pink or pale brownish (Option B) 5-9 days Less RBC but more leukocytes Wound exudate Mucus from the cervix Microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci) Lochia Alba-pale white ( Option C ) 10-15 days Decidual cells Leukocytes Mucus Cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells Microorganisms. Leukorrhea : Profuse white discharge might be seen in vaginitis, cervicitis, or subinvolution ( Option D ) . Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page 636 2. DC Dutta Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page138

questions.question: During postpartum care, a 32-year-old woman who delivered a healthy baby 2 days ago asks about changes in her body during this period. All of the following statements accurately reflect these changes except?

options.A: Cervix becomes firm after delivery and closes by 3 weeks
options.B: Patient presenting with retained bits requires manual evacuation
options.C: Woman is most susceptible to cervical dysplasia after delivery
options.D: Rugae starts to reform by 2nd to 3rd week

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Patient presenting with retained bits requires manual evacuation Explanation: If a patient presents with retained bits during puerperium, it requires surgical evacuation after dilatation and not manual evacuation (manual evacuation is done for retained placenta) Changes seen postpartum: Cervix Becomes firm after delivery and closes by 3 weeks ( Option A ) Epithelium starts to regrow Transformation zone starts to reform → Exposure to HPV at this stage → More susceptible to Ca cervix ( Option C ) Note: Woman is most susceptible to cervical dysplasia/ cancer immediately after delivery and early in puberty Vagina Starts shrinking Rugae starts to reform from 2nd to 3rd week onwards ( Option D ) Epithelium starts to grow by 6 weeks (4 - 6 weeks) Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page 635 2. DC Dutta Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page 138

questions.question: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman presents on postoperative day 4 following an uncomplicated cesarean section delivery due to prolonged labor. She complains of increasing lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, and fever. On examination, her abdomen is tender over the uterine incision site, and she has mild tachycardia. On investigation, her WBC count was 14,500. What is the preferred treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Amoxiclav Explanation: Amoxicillin + Clavulanic acid (amoxiclav) is the Gold Standard treatment for Endometritis. Puerperal Fever: A rise of temperature reaching 100.4°F (38°C) or more (measured orally) on two separate occasions at 24 hours apart (excluding first 24 hours) within the first 10 days following delivery is called puerperal pyrexia. Causes of Puerperal Fever: Endometritis(most common) Breast engorgement Respiratory infection Pyelonephritis Thrombophlebitis Endometritis: Postpartum uterine infection has been called endometritis, endomyometritis, and endoparametritis. Infection involves the myometrium and parametrial tissues and not just the decidua alone. Clinical Features: Signs: Investigations: Treatment: Fever Pain abdomen Dirty, foul-smelling discharge Lower abdomen tenderness On P/V examination: - Uterine and Adnexal tenderness - Fullness in Pouch of Douglas Leukocytosis Raised ESR & CRP High PCT Amoxicillin + Clavulanic acid ( Gold Standard ) Clindamycin + Aztreonam (for Renal insufficiency) Vancomycin (adjuvant therapy in suspected cases of MRSA) Ampicillin is added to Clindamycin and Gentamicin when there is sepsis or a suspected Enterococcal infection. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition , Page: 650, 651, 652, 653

questions.question: A 30-year-old postnatal mother comes with bleeding PV and lower abdominal cramps, 3 weeks postpartum. USG shows an enlarged uterus and tubular hypoechoic areas in the myometrium. The mother is stable. On bimanual examination, the uterus is larger and softer than normal. She is diagnosed with subinvolution. What is the most common cause of the given diagnosis in her case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Retained Placental Fragments Explanation: Subinvolution occurs when the uterus fails to return to its normal size after delivery. The most common cause of subinvolution is retained placental fragments. These fragments prevent the uterus from contracting effectively and undergoing normal involution. Subinvolution Definition The uterus fails to return to its normal size after delivery. Pathogenesis Retained Placental Fragments Incompletely Remodeled Spiral Arteries Infection (most common cause) Clinical features Prolonged Lochia. Irregular/Excessive Uterine Bleeding. Investigations Bimanual Examination: The Uterus is larger and softer than normal. HPE: Perivascular Trophoblasts are seen in Vessel walls - Aberrant Interaction between uterine and trophoblast cells USG Pelvis: Enlarged Uterus with Tubular Hypoechoic areas in the Myometrium. These tubular areas reflect neovascularization and dilated uterine vessels. Treatment Uterotonics. Methergine (Methylergonovine) 0.2mg every 4 hrs for 24-48hrs. IM dose of Methergine + Infusion of Synthetic Oxytocin in 1L Crystalloid. Suspected cases of Infection are treated with Azithromycin, Amoxicillin-Clavulanate or Doxycycline. Curettage is done if bleeding recurs after medical management. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Pages 636, 637.

questions.question: A 22-year-old mother feels her 6 day old baby seems to be getting only a small amount of thick, yellowish fluid while breastfeeding, despite proper latch and positioning. She gets anxious, and stressed about it. What is the most likely reason for the difficulty with milk ejection during breastfeeding?

options.A: Increased glucocorticoid levels due to stress
options.B: Decreased oxytocin release due to anxiety

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Decreased oxytocin release due to anxiety Explanation: In this scenario the thick, yellowish fluid is colostrum and maternal anxiety and stress is interfering with the milk ejection reflex causing difficulty in milk ejection. Milk ejection reflex also known as letting down reflex , is initiated mainly by suckling action of the baby, stimulating the posterior pituitary to secrete oxytocin in a pulsatile fashion which causes contraction of myoepithelial cells in alveoli and milk ducts to express the milk. Factors promoting let-down reflex Factors inhibiting let-down reflex (option B) Infant cry Frequent feeding Proper positioning and latching Pain Breast engorgement Maternal stress, anxiety and depression Types of milk Stage of puerperium Morphology Contents Colostrum 0 to 5 days Yellow, thick High in protein vitamin A sodium chloride lower carbohydrate, fat and potassium Growth factors Transitional 5 days to 2 weeks Bluish white, thinner High in fat and lactose Increased calories Mature From 2 weeks onwards White, watery Adequate quantity of fats, protein and carbohydrates Large amounts of water Note: immunoglobulin A (IgA), complements, macrophages, lymphocytes, lactoferrin and lactoperoxidase are present in all the types of milk. Glucocorticoids (Option A) and prolactin (Option C) are involved in lactogenesis. Progesterone (Option D) inhibits lactogenesis. Also, it does not play a role in milk ejection.

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman, two weeks postpartum, is concerned about decreased milk production as her baby shows signs of hunger. On evaluation with blood tests reveal low levels of a certain hormone. Which hormone is most likely to be low?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Prolactin Explanation: Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone. Hormones and breast milk production: Prolactin levels fall after delivery and the basal levels are low in postpartum period Episodic rise is required for subsequent lactation and maintenance in the postpartum period, which happens during each act of suckling. Hormones that favor milk production Hormones that inhibit milk production Prolactin (Option B) Insulin Glucocorticoids Growth hormone Thyroxine Estrogen (Option C) Progesterone (Option D) Oxytocin is involved primarily in milk ejection, not production. (Option A)

questions.question: A 28 year-old HIV+ pregnant female who is on ART delivered a male baby, she is being treated for latent TB and also has Hepatitis B infection with low viral load. Immediately after the delivery the baby was given Hepatitis B immunoglobulin. What advice would you give to the mother regarding breastfeeding?

options.A: She can breastfeed the baby without any restrictions
options.B: Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother is HIV+
options.C: Should not breastfeed as the mother is not receiving treatment for Hepatitis B
options.D: Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother has HIV, Latent TB and Hepatitis B infection.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) She can breastfeed the baby without any restrictions Explanation: Despite all 3 conditions, baby can be breastfed as HIV is not a contraindication for breastfeeding in India and the mother is also on treatment for latent TB, and the baby has been given Hepatitis B immunoglobulin. Contraindications of Breastfeeding: Maternal causes Uncontrolled alcohol and drug abusers Active or untreated Tb Active herpes infection with lesion on breast Undergoing breast cancer treatment On drugs like cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine,doxorubicin, methotrexate,mycophenolate Fetal causes Galactosemia Prophylaxis for baby HIV- give neviripine to baby Untreated TB- INH prophylaxis to baby Hepatitis B infection-Vaccine +IVIG to baby Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother is HIV+ - In developing countries like India, HIV is not a contraindication for breastfeeding. (Option B) Should not breastfeed as the mother is not receiving treatment for Hepatitis B - As the infant received Hepatitis B immunoglobulin breastfeeding is not contraindication. (Option C) Breastfeeding should be avoided as the mother has HIV, Latent Tb and Hepatitis B infection- not contraindication for breastfeeding (Option D) Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 641 2. https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_PPTCT.pdf 3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4181157/ 4. https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/perinatal-hepb/downloads/HepB-Provider-tipsheet-508.pdf

questions.question: A 28-year-old breastfeeding mother complains of severe pain, redness, and swelling in her left breast, along with fever and chills for 7 days. The patient was put on antibiotics for mastitis but there is no improvement, she also has history of recurrent mastitis. On examination, there is a large fluctuant mass on left side and tenderness is present. What is the next line of management of above conditions?

options.A: Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention
options.B: Stop breastfeeding, continue oral antibiotics and apply cold compresses
options.C: Drain the abscess, start antifungal treatment and wean the baby
options.D: Stop antibiotics, switch to IV antifungal treatment and continue breastfeeding

questions.explanation: prevention Correct Answer: A) Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention Explanation: From the given question, severe pain, redness, swelling along with fluctuating mass, and tenderness of left breast indicates breast abscess with mastitis. This is treated by drainage and antibiotics. Mastitis Definition Parenchymal infection of mammary glands Causative organism Staph. Aureus (most common), Streptococci (option C) Risk factors Difficult nursing, cracked nipples, oral antibiotic therapy Source of infection Newborn's throat and nose Treatment of Mastitis Analgesics Hot fomentation with breast milk expression Dicloxacillin, Erythromycin (in penicillin-resistant cases) Complications of Mastitis Breast abscess (Variable destruction of breast tissue by recurrent Mastitis) Treatment of Breast abscess Abscess is drained under LA by giving radical incision in most dependent part and breaking of loculi by finger exploration. Now the cavity is closed with gauze, which is replaced for every 24 hours till the cavity gets healed. Stop breastfeeding, continue oral antibiotics and apply cold compresses - abscess requires drainage and breastfeeding should continue to resolve the infection (Option B) Drain the abscess, start antifungal treatment and wean the baby - As it is a bacterial abscess antifungal treatment not indicated and breastfeeding shall be continued (Option C) Stop antibiotics, switch to IV antifungal treatment and continue breastfeeding - antifungal treatment not indicated. (Option D) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Pages 659,660

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Thyrotoxic phase Explanation: Postpartum thyroiditis: Definition Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum Etiology Autoimmune Factors : Autoimmune Thyroiditis : Postpartum thyroiditis is often an autoimmune condition, characterized by the presence of thyroid autoantibodies (e.g., anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies). Immune Rebound: After childbirth, the immune system rebounds from the immunosuppressed state of pregnancy, which can trigger an autoimmune attack on the thyroid. Genetic Predisposition Hormonal Changes Clinical manifestations It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression- Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A) Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B) The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D) . Investigation Thyroid Function Tests : TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase. Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase. Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase. Thyroid Antibodies : Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component. Treatment: Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg) Regular monitoring and long term follow up of the thyroid profile. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition , Page 1098

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman who had severe postpartum hemorrhage two months ago reports fatigue, inability to breastfeed, and decreased libido. She also has noted significant weight gain and cold intolerance. Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) MRI brain Explanation: Given the history of severe postpartum hemorrhage and the symptoms, Sheehan's syndrome (postpartum hypopituitarism) is suspected. MRI of the pituitary gland can reveal an empty sella or reduced pituitary size. Sheehan Syndrome: Definition Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage. Symptoms Failure to lactate Hypotension Hypoglycemia fatigue amenorrhea Hypothyroidism adrenal insufficiency decreased libido weight gain cold intolerance Diagnosis Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage. Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone). MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size. Treatment: Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed) Sheehan’s Syndrome should be differentiated from other conditions causing hypopituitarism such as pituitary apoplexy, hypothyroidism, Addison’s disease, empty sella syndrome, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, hypoprolactnemia.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman, G3P3 (gravida 3, para 3), presents at 12 weeks postpartum. She reports persistent low mood, loss of interest in activities, insomnia and social withdrawal. She denies any suicidal thoughts. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.A: Referral to a psychotherapist for cognitive-behavioral therapy
options.C: Start with Chlorpromazine and sublingual estradiol
options.D: Observation and reassessment after one month

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Referral to a psychotherapist for cognitive-behavioral therapy Explanation: The given clinical scenario with persistent low mood, loss of interest in activities, social withdrawal, and denial of suicidal thoughts presenting after 12 weeks points towards Postpartum Depression. The Scenario describes mild to moderate postpartum depression for which Psychotherapy is considered initially. If the response doesn't improve then antidepressants are considered. SSRIs are only considered initially in severe postpartum depression and in PPD that are not responsive to CBT. (Option B) Postpartum Blues Postpartum Depression Postpartum Psychosis Onset 4-5 days after delivery, lasts a few days Gradual onset over 4-6 months following delivery or abortion Sudden, typically within 4 days of delivery Duration Transient, lasts for a few days Can persist beyond postpartum period Can persist beyond postpartum period Symptoms Depression Anxiety Tearfulness Insomnia Negative feelings Loss of energy and appetite Insomnia Social withdrawal Irritability Suicidal attitude Fear Restlessness Hallucinations Delusions Disorientation Suicidal and infantile impulses Treatment Reassurance psychological support CBT SSRIs, estrogen Patch later. Urgent psychiatric consultation, hospitalization. Chlorpromazine, sublingual estradiol, lithium, ECT (if necessary) Prognosis Good Good with treatment High risk of recurrence Breastfeeding Generally safe Safe with SSRIs Contraindicated with some medications (Lithium) Start with Chlorpromazine and sublingual estradiol (Option C): It is used in the management of Postpartum Psychosis and has no role in Postpartum Depression. Observation and reassessment after one month (Option D): Delaying treatment for one month may worsen symptoms and affect the well-being of both the mother and baby. Prompt intervention is important to prevent complications associated with untreated PPD. Reference: 1. Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 1146 2. Dutta Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 415
